title: Teaching
text:
I currently teach courses in causal inference (MF9570), survival analysis (e.g. MF9510), introductory statistics (e.g. MF9130) and in other shorter courses for the PhD program at the Faculty of Medicine, University of Oslo.
In April 2024 I held an online ISCB course in biostatistics together with Ruth Keogh on causal inference for time-to-event outcomes with practical applications in R.

title: Research
text:
My main research interests are causal inference and time-to-event analysis. In particular, I have worked on methods for estimating the effects of time-varying treatments on survival outcomes under time-dependent confounding and multi-state modelling of event history data. I also have an interest in studies of infectious diseases, and have done some work on topics such as vaccine effectiveness, excess mortality, infectious disease surveillance and infectious disease modelling.
I am interested in applications using both randomised and observational data, and in particular event history outcomes construced using data from linked clinical and population-wide registries. I am currently involved in various collaborative projects, e.g. on the effects of rehabilitation and pain medication on patient outcomes after traumatic injury with researchers at the Oslo University Hospital, and on the effects of rehabilitation and workplace initiatives on long-term sick leave and work-related outcomes with researchers at the National Institute of Occupational Health in Norway. I currently lead research projects with funding from the Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, University of Oslo, and from the Research Council of Norway.
See my Google Scholar profile for publications.

title: Jon Michael Gran
text:
I am a professor of biostatistics at the Department of Biostatistics, University of Oslo, a part of the Oslo Centre of Biostatistics and Epidemiology. My research interests are in causal inference and survival/event history analysis.
I currently also have a 20% position at the Department of Method Development and Analytics, Division of Infection Control and Environmental Health, at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health. I have been an associate editor in Biometrika since 2018.
See also my web pages at the University of Oslo and the web pages of the causal inference and survival analysis group.
